author: jgm
content:
Agree with the above, staker is a role (the entity that stakes funds) that is separate from the validator (the program that validates the chain through creation of blocks, and validates blocks through the creation of attestations).

Beacon node is probably safer than consensus node, as there will likely be consensus nodes in lower layers as well.  The name is already relatively well-known and no harm in keeping it when no alternative will be better.

Execution or application node for the current ETH1 node also seems reasonable, although possibly a little generic.  But something like "EVM node" is just ugly.

author: sky.cactus
content: We should not be naming things with a target audience of existing developers and users, we should be naming things with a target audience of future developers and users.  The "harm" in naming things poorly is that it creates confusion for new developers and new users.  The goal with naming should be that someone new to the ecosystem can fairly quickly ramp up and get an intuitive idea for how the system works without needing to go rewrite their internal language=>concept mapping.

author: jgm
content:
The argument against calling it a "staking node/client/peer/whatever" is that it isn't actually staking.  Staking happens elsewhere, by a different entity.  The piece of software actually carries out a number of tasks:
  - proposing blocks
  - attesting to already-existing blocks
  - (informing beacon nodes about required network subscriptions)
  - (handling sync committees, come Altair)

none of these things are staking in the sense in which it is generally known.

Of course, none of these things are officially validating either, but we do need a name for the thing that does the first two operations.

I do think that some of the confusion is that "validate" can be active or passive.  The beacon node validates in the passive sense, in that it confirms that pre-existing information is correct and leads to the desired end state. author: sky.cactus
content: An ideal word is one that instills in the listener a clear and correct message with the least amount of prior context. author: jgm
content:
Question on rewards in Altair, and specifically sync committee rewards, from a quick read-through of the Altair spec.

Sync committee rewards are awarded for the 512 validators that are in the sync committee.  Given that there are well over 100,000 active validators, any given validator will be in a sync committee less than 0.5% of the time.

If an active validator is not in a sync committee it appears to be capped at 87.5% of full rewards, as the 8/64 contribution from contributing to the sync committee is not present.

So that appears to cap validator rewards in Altair to just over 7/8 of what they are today.  Or am I missing some weighting for validators not in the sync committee (or indeed overall) that balances this out?

author: ajsutton
content:
The way I look at most of these things is based on only paying the minimum necessary for the required security. So if you're not performing a duty there's no reason you should be paid for it.  And if there's a reduction in rewards but enough validators stick around then that's fine.  If we don't have enough validators then we should increase the max issuance to incentivise more to join.

Of course, in this period before withdrawals any reduction in rewards is pretty unfair and we should think carefully.  

We want to avoid being capricious but I do kind of like getting people used to the idea that we're actually trying to minimise their staking rewards (without too many of them leaving), not maximise them.

author: potuz
content: It'd be nice to know the rationale for these numbers though, the effects of Poisson distributions are already noticeable, if you take away slashings, the validators with most proposals and no downtime have earned considerably more than the validators with least proposals and no downtime for doing really the same job. I admittedly do not know the dangers of lowering the weight of proposals, but it is one of those places where someone has to put a finger and say "this is the ratio, we're going with 1/8 of earnings". The thing is that those 1/8 of earnings are being received now less frequently than monthly. And it will be less soon. The situation with the sync committee is also quite a lottery: you have 0,34% of chances of being in a committee every 2 days. So that's an expected median of over 4 months to being in one. If you run Kraken this doesn't matter. If you are a single staker this makes a difference. I get that there may be security reasons for these numbers, so I'll wait for the annotated spec to see if they are there. But it looks a bit extreme.
